entries: {@note An unlabelled version of the map can be found {@link here|https://raw.githubusercontent.com/TheGiddyLimit/homebrew/master/_img/ToB3-Lairs/map/11.jpg}.}

entries.name: 1. Main Tunnel

entries: The scent of musk assaults you as you enter the mouth of the cave. Ahead, the tunnel continues on into darkness. It is completely, eerily silent—and utterly dark and black.
The main tunnel is approximately 15 feet wide at its narrowest. It winds into the darkness of the mountainside.

entries.name: 2. Original Chamber

entries: This large chamber smells of stale musk and a slight hint of rot. Some old bones are scattered about, long-ago stripped of their flesh, and there are tufts of gold and brown fur that have collected at the edges of the room.
This oblong chamber, which was the original cave carved by the {@creature catamount|ToB3}, measures roughly 30 feet by 55 feet.

entries.name: 3. Pit Trap

entries: This portion of the hallway widens slightly, like a bulge in a weakened vein. You see more detritus of bones and fur, and, ahead, you can see that the cavern continues north then bends westward.

The floor in the center of the room is thin and easily broken. Creatures weighing more than 100 lbs. (including their gear) must make a DC 14 Dexterity saving throw when they enter the space; on a failure, the false floor breaks beneath them in a 5-foot square, and they fall 30 feet into the pit below, taking 10 ({@damage 3d6}) bludgeoning damage from the fall and landing {@creature prone}.

To climb out of the pit, a creature must succeed on a DC 18 Strength ({@skill Athletics}) check; using a rope and {@item grappling hook|phb} or other climbing gear grants advantage on the roll. If more than one PC avoids falling into the pit and can lower a rope, together, with 10 minutes of work, they can help any fallen compatriots escape the trap.
The pit spans a 20-foot square in the center of the room. The {@creature catamount|ToB3} can pass through this area without triggering the trap.

entries.name: 4. Main Tunnel Continuation
entries: When the PCs pass the pit trap and enter this portion of the tunnel, they can make a DC 15 Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check. On a success, they hear the sound of hushed bickering from up ahead, and any PC that speaks {@language goblin} recognizes it as that language, though they can't quite make out what's being said beyond the words "gonna wait"; on a result of 18 or higher, they are able to determine that the bickering is coming from the goblin war band (see {@area 6|11.6|u}) arguing about how or when to proceed against the {@creature catamount|ToB3}, since their scout Brux has not returned.

entries.name: 5. Another Old Den
entries: The room holds nothing of interest and is almost identical to {@area 2|11.2|u}.

entries.name: 6. False Den
entries: This room is also very similar to {@area 2|11.2|u}, except for its {@creature goblin} occupants.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: A war band of eight {@creature goblin||goblins} huddle together in this room, arguing about whether or not they should attack the {@creature catamount|ToB3} now or wait. They are not immediately hostile, but fight if attacked.

When the PCs enter this room, the {@creature goblin||goblins} draw their weapons and back against the southern wall as far from the PCs as they can get. A successful DC 14 Charisma ({@skill Deception}, {@skill Intimidation}, or {@skill Persuasion}) check convinces the {@creature goblin||goblins} to put away their weapons and talk. The leader of the band identifies herself as Herx.

entries.name: Development
entries: The {@creature goblin||goblins} are part of a hunting party there to kill the {@creature catamount|ToB3} and claim the lair for themselves. One of their member, Brux, went ahead to scout the den (see {@area 10|11.10|u}), and they are waiting for him to return before making their final push. A successful DC 18 Charisma ({@skill Deception}, {@skill Intimidation}, or {@skill Persuasion}) check is necessary to convince the {@creature goblin||goblins} to fight alongside the PCs; otherwise they are content—now that the brave adventurers are here—to wait for them to kill the {@creature catamount|ToB3} and then claim the lair for themselves.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Along with the gear listed in their stat block, the {@creature goblin||goblins} each carry 15 cp.

entries.name: 7. Waste Room

entries: While the ground has been mostly firm, hard-packed earth elsewhere in the den, in this chamber the dirt is loose and clearly has been disturbed with some frequency. A slight acrid scent fills the air, sharper than the scent of musk you've detected thus far.
This chamber is simply the {@creature catamount|ToB3|catamount's} "litter box," though since it can literally move earth at will, it buries its urine and feces thoroughly.

entries.name: 8. Yet Another Old Den
entries: Another old den, mostly identical to {@area 2|11.2|u}, but the southwestern corner of the chamber shows sign of collapse, as if the {@creature catamount|ToB3} had been trying to tunnel further westward, but the earth was too unstable.
This empty cavern once served as the {@creature catamount|ToB3|catamount's} primary nesting area, but has since been abandoned.

entries.name: 9. Funnel
entries: The tunnel widens to a bulb, with the only exit leading to the west to {@area 10|11.10|u}.

entries.name: 10. Nest

entries: The cavern widens ahead, opening into an enormous chamber. At the far western end sits a large stone, bowlshaped nest. The bowl is formed of the same stone as the floor, in one continuous piece. The bowl looks to be lined with fur, and two newly-born kits rest within, so young that their eyes are still shut. Lying in front of the stone nest and feasting on the carcass of a goblin is an enormous catlike creature with gold and brown fur.

The lip of the stone nest rises 5 feet off the ground, and the interior depression is 2 feet deep. The kits within are newborns and defenseless; at this young age, they're Small creatures, just over 2 feet in length.
The goblin carcass is that of Brux, the scout mentioned in {@area 6|11.6|u}.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: As soon as the PCs enter this room, the {@creature catamount|ToB3} poises itself to attack.

entries.name: Tactics
entries: The {@creature catamount|ToB3|catamount's} primary concern is the safety of its kits. It attacks whatever creature moves closest to the nest and uses its Control Earth ability to inhibit any intruders from reaching the kits.

If the {@creature catamount|ToB3|catamount's} health is reduced by half (55 hit points or lower if it started the combat with full health, 25 hit points or lower if it started the combat with half health), it uses its Fissure ability to create a rift between the intruders and the kits, then leaps across it and attempts to lure the PCs out of the den and back out into the wilderness.

entries.name: Diplomacy
entries: The {@creature catamount|ToB3} is a beast, so PCs may attempt to cast spells such as {@spell speak with animals} to attempt to resolve the situation peacefully. It is intelligent enough to be able to reason, but its instincts are currently driving it to protect its young at all costs. Because of this, any attempt to reason with the {@creature catamount|ToB3} requires a successful DC 18 Charisma ({@skill Deception} or {@skill Persuasion}) or Wisdom ({@skill Animal Handling}) check, made with disadvantage—unless the PCs demonstrate any magic or abilities that show that they too are capable of manipulating earth. If there is any attempt to use Charisma ({@skill Intimidation}), the {@creature catamount|ToB3} attacks. If the PCs don't offer a reasonable solution as part of their entreaty, the attempt at diplomacy automatically fails, and the {@creature catamount|ToB3} attacks.

entries.name: Concluding the Adventure
entries: The adventure concludes when the {@creature catamount|ToB3} is killed or is otherwise no longer a threat to the area.

If the situation is resolved peacefully and the PCs convince the {@creature catamount|ToB3} to relocate and/or provide it with ways to protect its kits and survive without harming townsfolk, the {@creature catamount|ToB3} considers the PCs friends for life. If the PCs ever encounter the creature again, it remembers them and greets them (over)enthusiastically like a lost pet being reunited with its person.

If any of the {@creature goblin||goblins} remain alive, they move into the den if the {@creature catamount|ToB3} is either killed or removed, claiming the tunnels as their new home. After a week, a clan of 30 {@creature goblin||goblins} takes up residence there. The {@creature goblin||goblins} are wary of being too much of a threat to Bay's Burrow, as they don't want the wrath of the city—or adventurers—brought down upon them, but they attack lone travelers when the opportunity arises, and occasionally raid caravans on the trade route.

The {@creature catamount|ToB3} kits are too young to survive on their own; if left behind in the den, they starve to death in a manner of days—if the {@creature goblin||goblins} don't kill them first. If taken from the den, the kits can be hand-reared and relocated elsewhere once they are old enough to hunt on their own. Particularly bold adventurers may attempt to keep the {@creature catamount|ToB3|catamounts} as pets or animal companions. If kept as animal companions, they are completely helpless for a week, after which they use the statistics for a {@creature badger}; at 3 months, they use the statistics for a {@creature giant badger}; at 6 months, they use the statistics for a {@creature brown bear}. Once the kits are roughly 1 year of age, they mature into adult {@creature catamount|ToB3|catamounts} (and then use the full {@creature catamount|ToB3} stat block) and become too large to keep—and their instincts drive them to hunt, establish territory, and build a den. Alternatively, there is a market for two such kits, if the PCs know where to look.

When the {@creature catamount|ToB3} has been dealt with, Perinigan is thankful to the PCs for making the roads safe for travel again. If they offer to accompany him back to Sarra, he happily accepts the company and starts off the next morning. Terran also accompanies Perinigan—the two have hit it off over the past few days of sharing drinks and commiserating and have been discussing the possibility of merging their two businesses.

rows: {@b An adventure for four to five characters of 5th level}

entries.name: Adventure Background
entries: Spiteful Keep sits atop a small peak near a trade rode, amid a small forest. It is the home of an ogre artisan of the arcane who self-styles himself as "Lord" Gorgo. Only the bravest or most desperate dare to seek audience with the ogre

entries.name: Adventure Hook
entries: The following can used to start the PCs on this adventure:

items: {@b {@i To Lift a Curse.}} A local knight named Veladra is cursed. She purchased a sword from Gorgo, years past, when she was an adventurer. Gorgo recently sought her aid and was rebuffed. The ogre activated the curse, to make the knight give in to his demands. Instead, she hires the PCs to take care of the problem, by killing Gorgo or bringing him the sword and getting him to remove the curse.

{@b {@i Vanishing Goods.}} Yintalyn, the head of a town council at a nearby settlement, is concerned about a series of mysterious recent thefts. Rare and precious materials simply vanish, disappearing from locked strongboxes in merchant wagons. There are no witnesses or clues; things simply vanish. The authorities eventually realize that all of the goods stolen are useful in magical crafting. Gorgo immediately comes under suspicion. The PCs are hired to investigate Gorgo's keep and put a stop to these thefts.

{@b {@i In the Market for Magic.}} A wizard by the name of Gelarien is in need of a certain magic item and knows that Gorgo is the only artisan skillful enough to craft such a thing. She hires the PCs to make the journey to Gorgo's keep and convince the ogre to craft the item. In truth, Gelarien is a fake name, and the wizard was once wronged by Gorgo, and her true wish is that the PCs go there and will kill the ogre, who will not view an uninvited visit kindly.

entries.name: Spiteful Keep
entries: This keep is the home of Lord Gorgo, a {@creature cunning artisan ogre|ToB3}. The fortress is quite old, but well-maintained and well-fortified, with a curtain wall bolstered by five round towers and a gatehouse.

entries.name: Approaching the Keep
entries: As the PCs approach the keep within sight of any of its towers, they hear the sound of a distinctive whistle from above, clearly a signal of some kind alerting the keep that visitors are approaching.

entries.name: Keep Denizens
entries: The keep's denizens are utterly under the thrall of Lord Gorgo, and, indeed, they truly believe he's a great man and a master artisan worthy of following. The keep denizens include: 16 {@creature hobgoblin||hobgoblins}, a {@creature bugbear}, a {@creature daeodon|ToB3}, 4 {@creature goblin||goblins}, {@creature kobold ettin|ToB3}, a {@creature dokkaebi|ToB3} , and Lord Gorgo himself. All of the denizens (except the {@creature goblin||goblins}) are loyal to Gorgo and won't act contrary to his orders, even to save the life of one of their fellows.

entries.name: Gorgo's Jape
entries: One day, years ago, Gorgo demanded that his followers always refer to him as "Lord Gorgo, my mighty master"; he'd intended it as a jape that wouldn't last more than a day or two, but it pleased him so much he never rescinded the order. As a result, any time any of the keep denizens refer to Gorgo, they specifically use the words "{@i Lord Gorgo, my mighty master}."
{@note An unlabelled version of the map can be found {@link here|https://raw.githubusercontent.com/TheGiddyLimit/homebrew/master/_img/ToB3-Lairs/map/12.jpg}.}

As you approach the keep's iron-banded, oaken gates of the gatehouse, a slit slides open behind a small metal grate in the door and a pair of yellow eyes peer out from behind it. "What's your business here?" a voice demands.

entries.name: Polite Approach
entries: If the PCs are polite and present a reasonable story for why they're there, the guard tells them to wait there, and one of them will go see if Lord Gorgo is willing to meet with them. After a long time—long enough for the PCs to start to get impatient—the guard comes back and says, "Lord Gorgo, my mighty master, has agreed to an audience. Follow me." The guard leads the PCs to {@area 9|12.9|u}.

entries.name: Aggressive Approach
entries: If the PCs are overtly aggressive or insulting, the guards refuse them entry; once insulted, the guards can be convinced to hear the PCs out with a successful DC 17 Charisma ({@skill Deception}, {@skill Intimidation}, or {@skill Persuasion}) check; if Charisma ({@skill Intimidation}) is attempted, the check is made with disadvantage. On a failure, the guards demand they leave.

If the PCs refuse to leave or try to attack the guards, they sound the alarm, which results in a volley of arrows from the guards in {@area 15|12.15|u} and in the two southernmost towers ({@area 3|12.3|u}).

entries.name: Inside the Gatehouse
entries: The keep's outer gate opens into a small chamber with arrowslits on the eastern and western walls and murder holes in the ceiling above.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: Four {@creature hobgoblin||hobgoblins} are stationed here at any given time—two in the main gatehouse entryway and one each in the chambers to the east and west, manning the arrowslits; the latter are armed with {@item pike|phb|pikes} and {@item heavy crossbow|phb|heavy crossbows}, which they use to attack hostile creatures through the arrowslits.
If combat ensues here, the two hobgoblins in {@area 15|12.15|u} provide archery support from above, raining arrows down through the murder holes.

entries.name: Arrowslits
entries: The arrowslits provide the guards within with three-quarters cover. The chamber behind each arrowslit contains a pair of chairs and an iron ladder leading to {@area 15|12.15|u}.

entries.name: Inner Gate
entries: On the northern wall of the entryway are the inner gates that lead to the keep proper. Like the outer gates, these are iron-banded and made of solid oak. They have AC 19, 27 hit points, and a damage threshold of 10. The inner gates are barred on the courtyard side, requiring someone inside the keep—normally one of the arrowslit guards—to open them.

entries.name: Sound the Alarm!
entries: If the keep's denizens are alerted to their compatriots being attacked—either by the alarm being sounded or by the clamor of battle—they converge on the threat and all fight to the death (except the {@creature goblin||goblins}, who surrender or flee at the first opportunity).
If this occurs, it is likely to go very poorly for the PCs, as they're considerably outnumbered and would be fighting foes with superior fortified positioning.

entries.name: 2. Courtyard

entries: This large, open area is mostly packed earth with a few patches of scrubby grass. Outbuildings sit in the shelter of the keep's walls, while a covered well stands in the center of the courtyard. A pile of refuse has been dumped beside the north wall between the main building and the tower.

The courtyard is often unoccupied, except for Gorgo's pet {@creature daeodon|ToB3}, Gouger. The beast can usually be found in a wallow it has dug between the smithy ({@area 4|12.4|u}) and the westernmost tower, or it is sometimes found feeding in the refuse pile on the north side of the courtyard.
Occasionally two or more {@creature hobgoblin||hobgoblins} from the barracks ({@area 4|12.4|u}) can be found here training.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: Lord Gorgo's pet {@creature daeodon|ToB3} Gouger has the run of the courtyard most of the time. The {@creature daeodon|ToB3} is still half wild, and only Gorgo can command the beast. He readily attacks any creature he does not recognize, unless commanded otherwise by Gorgo—or unless that creature is in the company of one or more {@creature hobgoblin||hobgoblins}.

entries.name: 3. Tower, Ground Floor

entries: This small, round room is empty except for a narrow staircase that winds its way up the side of the tower to the floor above.
All five of the keep's towers are identical. The stairs wind up to the tower's upper level ({@area 16|12.16|u}).

entries.name: 4. Smithy

entries: A roofed, outdoor area on the north side of this stone structure contains a forge and anvil.
This building houses the keep's smithy, consisting of the forge, a small storage room, and a room containing a bed and small table, where the smith sleeps and takes his meals.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: Khorr, the {@creature bugbear} blacksmith, is typically found here at work in front of the forge.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: A set of smith's tools, 50 5-pound ingots of iron (worth 25 gp total), a sack containing 3 1-pound silver ingots (worth 15 gp total), and a pouch containing 20 sp and 13 gp.
This wooden building has a large set of double doors facing the center of the courtyard. Above the doors, you can see a block and tackle in front of an opening into a loft above.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: This is the keep's stables. Inside are 8 stalls, half of them occupied by {@creature riding horse||riding horses}. The other stalls are unoccupied.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The stable holds saddles, saddlebags, and bits and bridles for four horses.

This one-story stone building holds four bunk beds, each with footlockers beneath them. A long table and four chairs take up one side of the room. Two cast iron wood stoves sit in the northeast and southeast corners.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: There are up to 8 {@creature hobgoblin||hobgoblins} here. If alerted by an alarm or the sound of fighting, they rush to reinforce their allies. There is a {@chance 50|50% chance} that any {@creature hobgoblin} located here is asleep. In that case, their AC is only 13.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: In the footlockers is a total of 700 sp and 400 gp.

Iron pots bubble away in the large fireplace in the southwest corner of this room. A large, metal sink, work table and tall stools, and a set of shelves take up most of the space. An iron rack hung with various cookware, utensils, and bundles of drying herbs is suspended over the table.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: Four {@creature goblin||goblins} work here, preparing food for Gorgo and his followers. They won't attack the PCs, though will defend themselves; at the first opportunity, they attempt to flee through {@area 8|12.8|u}.

entries.name: 8. Pantry/Storage

entries: One side of this room is stacked with crates, barrels, and sacks, while the other is occupied by coils of rope, stacks of lumber, and more assorted crates and barrels.
This room serves as a pantry for the kitchen, containing general staples and various beers and wines.

entries.name: 9. Main Hall

entries: A large fireplace dominates the wall opposite the door. A long table stretches nearly the length of the room, surrounded by tall-backed chairs. At one end of the table sits a large, throne-like chair of wrought iron, set with leather cushions. A massive chandelier festooned with candles hangs above the table.

This room serves as a dining hall and Gorgo's audience chamber. When Gorgo is receiving visitors, {@creature goblin} minions bring in drinks and appetizers, then return to the kitchen ({@area 7|12.7|u}).

entries.name: Secret Door
entries: A successful DC 17 Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check notices a secret door at the southern end of the eastern wall that opens into the stairwell.

entries.name: Audience with Gorgo
entries: If the PCs attempt to reason with Gorgo, he quietly listens, politely nodding. The conversation plays out differently depending on which adventure hook you used, but in all cases almost everything he says is a lie; the PCs can discern this with a successful DC 17 Wisdom ({@skill Insight}) check.

entries.name: To Lift a Curse
entries: Gorgo explains that he made some youthful mistakes, this unpleasant situation with Veladra being one of them. He says he will gladly accede to this most reasonable request. He calls out to a guard in the hall, "Kludek, have Shovar bring me my toolbox."

entries.name: Vanishing Goods
entries: Gorgo seems surprised and distressed at this news and says that he'll question his majordomo about this immediately, as it is clearly unacceptable. He calls out to a guard in the hall, "Kludek, have Shovar come down here."

entries.name: A Wanting Wand
entries: Gorgo is dismayed at this news. He pulls on a glove and asks to see the wand. After examining it a moment, he says "Ah yes, this is my apprentice's work. I do apologize. He still has a lot to learn, it seems." He calls out to a guard in the hall, "Kludek, have Shovar come down here."

entries.name: Ambush Code
entries: "Kludek, have Shovar . . ." is code to prepare an attack. Gorgo makes pleasant small talk while waiting. After 5 minutes pass, the {@creature kobold ettin|ToB3} Squib-Jib (see {@area 10|12.10|u}) comes barreling through the secret door at the same time as two {@creature hobgoblin||hobgoblins} burst in through the regular door—and combat ensues; if it does, see the "Encountering Gorgo" sidebar.

entries.name: Encountering Gorgo
entries: The upper level of the keep is the private domain of Lord Gorgo. Only his servants and select visitors ever see this level of the keep. Gorgo is equally likely to be found in {@area Areas 11|12.11|x}, {@area 12|12.12|x}, or {@area 13|12.13|x}. Less frequently, he is in {@area 14|12.14|u}, consulting with his prisoner, or escorting Kwon to his workshop for assistance with something he's working on.

entries.name: 10. Upper Hallway
entries: A set of stone steps leads to the upper level of the keep. The upper hallway stretches the length of the building. Heavy wooden shutters cover the four windows on the northern wall.

entries.name: Magical Trap
entries: If a creature steps into the hallway from the stairs without first saying the words "Lord Gorgo, my mighty master," a bolt of lightning streaks down the hall. Each creature in the path of the bolt must make a DC 14 Dexterity saving throw. A creature takes 22 ({@damage 4d10}) lightning damage on a failed save or half as much damage on a successful one.
Once triggered, the trap is expended and takes 10 minutes to recharge.

entries.name: Trap Prevention
entries: On the face of the top step, a successful DC 12 Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check notices that the words "Say Hail" have been scratched into the stone. Other than uttering the passphrase, the only way to bypass the trap is to sense the magical trigger using {@spell detect magic}; if discovered in this way, a successful DC 15 Intelligence ({@skill Arcana}) check determines how to dissipate the trap's magical charge harmlessly, nullifying it for 10 minutes while it recharges.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: Squib-Jib, a {@creature kobold ettin|ToB3}, is around the corner, in the hall leading to {@area 14|12.14|u}. If the trap is triggered, they are alerted to intruders and come to investigate.

entries.name: Gorgo's Demeanor
entries: If confronted with intruders, Gorgo's response depends on their numbers, posture, and attitude. He attempts to parley with intruders in the hopes of lulling them into a false sense of safety. If they are openly hostile, Gorgo attacks and/or defends himself.

entries.name: Alertness
entries: If the trap in {@area 10|12.10|u} is triggered, Gorgo is alerted to the PCs' presence. If combat with Squib-Jib then ensues, Gorgo joins the fray after 1 round, throwing open the door of {@area 11|12.11|u} and activating his {@item gem of brightness}, even if Squib-Jib is in the line of fire.

entries.name: Combat Tactics
entries: Gorgo fights to the death, unless he sees an opportunity to escape to another location where his minions can join the battle. He uses his {@item gem of brightness} every turn (since he can activate it with a bonus action), with no regard for saving any of its charges.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Gorgo wears a fine {@item breastplate|phb}, though it only fits a Large creature. He also carries a {@item battleaxe|phb}, a {@item gem of brightness}, the keys to the prison cell in {@area 14|12.14|u} and the chest located in {@area 12|12.12|u}.
The walls of this room are hung with thick tapestries, and the floor covered in fur rugs. A large, overstuffed chair with a matching footstool sits in one corner next to a carved wooden cabinet.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: Inside the cabinet are a silver tray and goblet set (worth 50 gp), 2 crystal decanters (worth 40 gp total), a carved teakwood pipe (worth 15 gp), and a pouch of fine, apple-flavored tobacco (worth 35 gp). On the chair is a large tome about curses (worth 10 gp).

entries.name: 12. Bedroom

entries: A massive bed, piled with furs, takes up most of the room. A round table stands on one side of it, a chest on the other. A tall wardrobe stands in one corner, a freestanding, ten-foot-tall ovoid mirror in the other. There is a single, shuttered window in the center of the southern wall and a closed door on the eastern wall.
The wardrobe contains {@item fine clothes|phb|fine clothing} (but very large). The table holds a ceramic washbasin and an ewer full of water.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The chest is locked, but can be picked with a successful DC 15 Dexterity check using thieves' tools. Gorgo holds the key. It contains 10,000 sp, 1,000 gp, and a large gold bracelet worth 250 gp.

entries.name: 13. Magical Workshop

entries: Tables cluttered with tools, alchemical ingredients, and piles of notes line the walls of this room. A shelf full of old tomes stands against one wall. A round table is located in the southwest corner, a large chair next to it. On the table are a number of engraving tools, as well as an adjustable stand holding a magnifying lens.
If Gorgo is encountered in this room, there is a {@chance 50|50% chance} he has Kwon ({@area 14|12.14|u}) with him.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: On the tables are sets of {@item alchemist's supplies|phb}, {@item calligrapher's supplies|phb}, {@item jeweler's tools|phb}, and {@item woodcarver's tools|phb}. There's also an assortment of gemstones, as well as gold and silver dust and wire (worth 500 gp total), and four {@item potion of healing||potions of healing}.

There are also several finished magic items here that function but also bear Gorgo's signature curses. Consult the "Gorgo's Cursed Items" table to see how each item is cursed; aside from the stated effects of the curses, the items work normally.

entries.caption: Gorgo's Cursed Items
rows: Curse of Cowardice: On any round in which you would otherwise be surprised, you can still act, but you must use your action to activate the ring and jump away from the nearest enemy.
Curse of Falsehood: There is a {@chance 50|50% chance} that one non-magical item in range is identified as magical.
Curse of Reciprocation: When you hit a creature with an attack using his magic weapon, the next attack the target makes against you has advantage.

entries.name: 14. Prison Cell

entries: This spartan chamber contains only a small cot and a chamber pot.
The door to this room is locked; Gorgo holds the key.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: Inside the room is Gorgo's prisoner, a {@creature dokkaebi|ToB3} named Kwon. The ogre forces the fey to summon items used in the creation of his magic items. Kwon is desperate to be free and is grateful to anyone that rescues him. He would rather flee immediately, but stays and helps his rescuers if he must. If attacked, he turns {@creature invisible} and attempts to flee.
The walls of this room feature several arrowslits. The room is empty other than a pair of small casks filled with arrows and the two hobgoblins standing watch.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: Two {@creature hobgoblin||hobgoblins} are on watch in this room at all times. Each {@creature hobgoblin} has a cask of 60 arrows to use in defense of the keep. If combat ensues in the courtyard, these guards use the inner arrowslits to rain arrows down on the intruders below.

entries.name: 16. Upper Tower

entries: The staircase emerges into a round room with arrowslits in the walls. A small cask of arrows sits in the center of the room.
All five of the keep's upper towers are identical. The stairs wind down to the tower's lower level ({@area 3|12.3|u}).

entries.name: Creatures
entries: Two {@creature hobgoblin||hobgoblins} stand watch at the top of each tower. Each {@creature hobgoblin} has a cask of 60 arrows to use in defense of the keep. If combat ensues in the courtyard, these guards use the inner arrowslits to rain arrows down on the intruders below.

entries.name: Escaping the Keep
entries: If the PCs wish to escape the keep without going through the gatehouse, they can do so—and get beyond the keep's curtain wall—by leaping or rappelling down via: (1) the windows on the northern wall in {@area 10|12.10|u} (30 feet to the ground); (2) the windows on the eastern wall in {@area 13|12.13|u} (20 feet to the ground); and (3) {@area 16|12.16|u}, the Upper Towers (70 feet to the ground).

entries.name: Concluding the Adventure
entries: The adventure comes to an end after the PCs conclude their visit to Spiteful Keep.
If Gorgo is killed, any other remaining denizens of the keep abandon the place for greener pastures.

If the PCs assault and/or raid the keep, but leave Gorgo alive, the ogre becomes an enemy who avenges himself at the most inopportune moment for the PCs. Any magic items taken from the keep may have their curses activated by him at a later date, possibly forcing another confrontation with the ogre to remove them.

rows: {@b An adventure for four to five characters of 5th level}

entries.name: Adventure Background
entries: High in the mountains, tunneled directly into one of the peaks, is the Abbey of the Serene Lily. The temple was founded by ascetic scholars from disparate nations who sought to overcome the differences between their respective peoples and live in peaceful contemplation. When acolytes leave the abbey, they often find positions as advisors and councilors to political and religious leaders in their home nations.

For the last several years, visitors to the abbey have returned to their homelands with tales of a mentor with powerful precognitive abilities. This teacher, the temple's leader, Abbot Qudos, is frequently sought after for advice on matters ranging from which suitor a young noblewoman should marry to how a trade mogul can maximize his profits on a given venture.

In truth, "Qudos" is a fiend who slayed the true Abbot Qudos and assumed his identity. He seeks to corrupt everyone he comes into contact with, and, over time, he has slain, supplanted, or sent away all of the noble monks and adepts of the abbey and replaced them with his own sycophantic followers.

entries.name: Adventure Hook
entries: The PCs have been asked to gain Abbot Qudos' counsel by a ruler whose nation suffered a cowardly attack by another nation. He doesn't wish to reignite the hostilities between the nations that has led to the loss of so many lives, but he also cannot afford to do nothing, lest it give his enemies free rein to do as they please against his people. It seems as if there is no good answer, and so Qudos' wisdom is needed.

entries.name: Mountain Hazards
entries: The abbey has been carved directly into the summit of a mountain (at 10,000 feet) located at the northwestern portion of the range. A narrow, steep—and sometimes precarious—trail winds up the mountain. A direct path, with no compilations, takes 12 hours, though attempting the trek all in one day incurs one level of {@condition exhaustion}; if the trip is split into two days of travel, the PCs can reach the summit without incurring levels of {@condition exhaustion}.

entries.name: Elevation Sickness
entries: Once the PCs reach the summit, whenever they complete a long rest, they must make a DC 13 Constitution saving throw; on a failed save, they gain a level of {@condition exhaustion} from the effects of high altitude and fail to recover any levels of {@condition exhaustion} they'd previously accrued. A PC accustomed to high altitudes automatically succeeds on this saving throw. After seven days at the summit, the PCs' bodies become inured to the rigors presented by the thinner air at the abbey and no longer have to make saving throws to avoid {@condition exhaustion}.

entries.name: Mountain Encounters
entries: Twice while the PCs are scaling the mountain, roll a {@dice d6}. On a result of 1 or 2, run one of the following encounters:

entries.name: Encounter 1: Alpine Creeper Ambush

entries: Up the mountainside, you see the rocky escarpment is dotted with patches of blue and green. As you get closer, you see it is a colorful moss or lichen that has adhered itself to the landscape.

As the PCs approach this hazard, allow them to spot the stray, partly submerged bones littering the ground with a successful DC 14 Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check, or if they have passive {@skill Perception} scores of 14 or higher. The bones are suspiciously humanoid and might alert the PCs to the impending threat.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: The lichen is comprised of two {@creature alpine creeper|ToB3|alpine creepers}. They can be evaded entirely by moving out of range. If the creepers knock all of the PCs {@condition unconscious}, some of the cultists from the abbey rescue them, and they later wake in {@area 5|13.5|u}.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: As the PCs move across a narrow shelf, they are charged by six {@creature cloudhoof assassin|ToB3|cloudhoof assassins}. The goat-like creatures seek to knock the PCs from the shelf so they can rest there themselves. Creatures knocked from the ledge fall 40 feet to another ledge below, taking {@damage 4d6} bludgeoning damage and falling {@condition prone}. The {@creature cloudhoof assassin|ToB3|cloudhoof assassins} cannot be reasoned with as long as the PCs are on the plateau, but each one retreats from the fight once it is reduced to 10 hit points or less.

entries.name: Abbey of the Serene Lily
entries: The abbey is built into the mountaintop and has no external profile other than the doors leading into it.

entries.name: Structure
entries: The floor of the abbey is comprised of 1-foot-square sandstone tiles. The walls are smooth stone and the ceiling is intermittently engraved with bas relief hummingbirds and lilies.

entries.name: Ceilings
entries: The corridors are 5 feet wide and 8 feet tall. The chambers have 15-foot ceilings.

entries.name: Lighting
entries: The abbey is dimly lit at all times through some form of magical ambient illumination.

entries.name: Incense
entries: The abbey smells of frankincense, which can be found burning in thuribles in each chamber. The pervasiveness of the odor is such that creatures making Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks based on smell have disadvantage.

The incense smoke masks the odor of the narcotic burning with it. When a creature in the abbey makes a saving throw against being {@condition charmed} or {@condition frightened}—or makes a Wisdom ({@skill Insight}) check to determine if a creature is telling the truth—it must subtract {@dice 1d4} from the number rolled. Creatures that are wearing some type of face covering—or who don't need to breathe—are not affected by the narcotic.

entries.name: Sound
entries: During daylight hours, the sound of someone playing the sitar can be heard. It is not uncommon to hear rhythmic chanting as well.

entries.name: Aspirants and Adepts
entries: There are twenty-seven {@creature serene lily aspirant|ToB3-Lairs|aspirants} (use statistics for {@creature cultist||cultists}) and seven {@creature serene lily adept|ToB3-Lairs|adepts} (use statistics for {@creature cult fanatic||cult fanatics}) residing at the abbey. All of the masters in the abbey are {@creature barbed devil||barbed devils} or {@creature bearded devil||bearded devils} in disguise.

entries.name: Creature Change
entries: Replace the {@creature serene lily aspirant|ToB3-Lairs|aspirant's} Scimitar action and the {@creature serene lily adept|ToB3-Lairs|adept's} Dagger action, with the following:

entries.name: Unarmed Strike
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 4} to hit, reach 5 ft., one creature. Hit: 5 ({@damage 1d6 + 2}) bludgeoning damage.

entries.name: Color Coding
entries: All of the residents of the abbey wear pale blue robes. Aspirants wear red sashes, adepts wear dark blue sashes, and masters wear black sashes.

entries.name: Monk Distribution
entries: The {@creature serene lily adept|ToB3-Lairs|adepts} and {@creature serene lily aspirant|ToB3-Lairs|aspirants} should be distributed throughout the abbey, with the following parameters depending on time of day:

items: In the morning, the majority are outside sparring in {@area 1|13.1|u}.
In the afternoon, they are praying in {@area 6|13.6|u}.
At night, they rest in {@area 5|13.5|u}.

entries.name: Lies and Lies
entries: The cultists frequently lie about the purpose of the abbey and the behavior of its inhabitants. Detecting this deception requires a successful DC 14 Wisdom ({@skill Insight}) check.

entries.name: Devils
entries: Each {@creature barbed devil} or {@creature bearded devil} encountered in the abbey is wearing a {@item hat of disguise}, using it to appear to be a master in pale blue robes with a black sash. A creature must make a successful DC 13 Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) check to detect the disguise.
{@note An unlabelled version of the map can be found {@link here|https://raw.githubusercontent.com/TheGiddyLimit/homebrew/master/_img/ToB3-Lairs/map/13.jpg}.}

entries.name: 1. Sparring Ground
entries: If the PCs approach in the morning, read or paraphrase the following:

Several pairs of robed people are sparring against each other in the large flat area before the abbey's entrance. Four calm-faced monks walk among them, correcting their stances and offering advice. A short walkway descends slightly to the carved double doors leading into the abbey itself.
If the PCs approach at any other time of day, read or paraphrase the following:

A large area in front of the entrance to the abbey has been worn flat by the repeated passage of many feet. It is curiously quiet here, with the ice-cold wind creating the only sound. A short walkway descends slightly to the carved double doors leading into the abbey itself.
This area is an expanse of dirt packed hard by years of sparring and treading upon it. A chill breeze blows dust and grit in eddies across the ground.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: In the morning, twenty {@creature serene lily aspirant|ToB3-Lairs|aspirants} are sparring here. Four {@creature serene lily adept|ToB3-Lairs|adepts} (the monks referenced in the boxed text above) walk among them. They are all barefoot, though some have wrapped their feet in white cloth strips.
The people in the area are polite, but don't have much to say and won't answer questions in any helpful way. They're likely to utter the phrase, "Abbot Qudos knows all."
The double doors that lead into the abbey have been skillfully carved in bas-relief with a scene of lilies blowing in the wind while hummingbirds sip nectar from the flowers.

entries.name: 2. Entrance

entries: Upon entering the abbey, your eyes are immediately drawn to a fountain featuring a jade statue of a robed female monk wrestling a giant carp. The smell of frankincense is strong, and the sound of a distant sitar being played can be heard. Two white-goateed monks approach to greet you.
Frankincense is burning in the censers that flank each of the passage entrances leading further into the abbey.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: The aged monks are Adept Toub and Adept Yestel (both LE {@creature serene lily adept|ToB3-Lairs|adepts}). They can answer the PCs questions and are willing to arrange for them to meet with Qudos the morning after they arrive.

Answers to some questions the PCs might ask over the course of their stay at the abbey follow. For questions that aren't presented here, the residents of the abbey answer deceptively about the purpose of the abbey, who Qudos is, and any activities that don't seem in-character for monks who seek serenity. If they feel that answering a question won't compromise them or the abbey, they answer truthfully.

items: {@b Q: Why can't we see Qudos sooner?}
A: "The abbot is on an Astral retreat searching for the true source of serenity." (This is a lie. Qudos and the cultists want the narcotic in the air to make the PCs as pliant as possible).
{@b Q: What is going on with the torture chamber?}

A: "Some of our adherents feel soothed following a brief but intense encounter with pain. The excruciation chamber allows them to reach bliss in a safe manner." (Technically true, though the abbey's current residents use the chamber to torture reluctant {@creature serene lily aspirant|ToB3-Lairs|aspirants} for information).

entries.name: Audience with Qudos
entries: If the PCs do have an audience with Abbot Qudos, it occurs in the morning in {@area 6|13.6|u}. During the brief meeting, the elderly, white-haired monk is polite and listens attentively before claiming he needs time to look into their concerns. He directs other inquiries to Master Ghi (LE {@creature barbed devil} in disguise).

Qudos is dressed as the other residents, but wears a white sash. His true nature is that he is a LE {@creature lesser infernal tutor|ToB3}; when he appears as a human, he does so using his Change Shape ability, and so is not using illusion magic to disguise himself as the other devils are.

entries.name: 3. Relaxation Room

entries: The scent of frankincense is overpowering in this chamber, and the air swirls with a pall of pale smoke. Aspirants sitting or lying on floor mats come here to take a moment to relax. A monk sits against the southwest wall idly playing a sitar.

Rectangular 3-foot by 6-foot jute mats are evenly spaced throughout this chamber, and it is rare for more than half of them to be occupied at any given time. Two large thuribles are always kept burning.
The PCs are welcome to rest in this chamber, and if they spend the night in the abbey, they are given quarters here rather than in the dormitory at {@area 5|13.5|u}.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: The sitar player is Master Kethi (LE {@creature barbed devil}). A successful DC 19 Intelligence ({@skill Religion}) check recognizes the music being played as being from {@i Hymns for the Acquisition of Glorious Wealth}, a prominent hymnal of a god of greed and wealth.

entries.name: Development
entries: If the PCs make trouble in {@area Areas 2|13.2|x}–{@area 7|13.7|u}, the {@creature barbed devil} investigates and assists the monks.

entries.name: 4. Kitchen and Dining Area

entries: The odor of frankincense, so prominent in the other areas of the abbey, is diminished beneath the smells of stir-frying vegetables and roasting barley flour. The grim-faced cook bustles silently around the area while preparing meals. The chamber has a slightly steamy haze from the lack of ventilation, and beads of condensation stand on the walls and ceiling.

During the day, a cauldron of water is kept at a low boil over an open flame, and a stone oven is kept heated. The cook, Jaitna, prepares all the food for the abbey. Most meals consist of a porridge of roasted barley, stir-fried roots and legumes, and butter tea.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: Aspirant Jaitna (N human {@creature acolyte}) is the only remaining holdout of the abbey's original residents. He refuses to break the vow of silence he took as a young monk, but a PC can intuit the intent and meaning of his expressions and gestures with a successful DC 15 Wisdom ({@skill Insight}) check. The result of one check is sufficient for each conversation. Jaitna is uncertain of the true nature of the changes at the abbey, but he knows Abbot Qudos and the black-sashed monks never eat, and he is certain they don't sleep either. He assists the PCs as he can, but he doesn't take violent action against any creature.

entries.name: 5. Dormitory

entries: Orderly rows of bunks fill this chamber. Each monk's belongings are rolled into a small bundle that sits at the foot of their cot. Censers set on low round tables burn the abbey's incense through the day and night.
The abbey's aspirants and adepts rest here. Occasionally, this chamber can be found empty during daylight hours.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: At night there are {@dice 15 + 1d6} {@creature serene lily aspirant|ToB3-Lairs|aspirants} and {@dice 1d6} {@creature serene lily adept|ToB3-Lairs|adepts} present here.

entries.name: Development
entries: A PC that succeeds on a DC 17 Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check while looking for secret doors finds the secret door leading to Qudos' chamber ({@area 8|13.8|u}). A successful DC 17 Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) check is then needed to determine how to open the secret door.
If the PCs are detected searching or stealing in this room, the aspirants and adepts attempt to detain and secure them in {@area 7|13.7|u}.

entries.name: 6. Central Chamber

entries: Murmured chanting and singing can be heard as you approach the central chamber. The vast room is some 50 feet in diameter. At the northern side is a short staircase leading up to a wide dais with four burning braziers upon it.

The monks of the abbey spend their afternoons in peaceful meditation in the large central chamber. After lunch, most of the aspirants and adepts kneel or sit crosslegged on jute mats and chant or sing their prayers. PCs that understand {@language Infernal} recognize that the prayers are a supplication for Mammon's beneficence.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: Prayers are led by Master Miloch (LE {@creature bearded devil} in disguise) and Master Ghi. During prayer time in the afternoon, there are {@dice 15 + 1d6} {@creature serene lily aspirant|ToB3-Lairs|aspirants} and {@dice 1d6} {@creature serene lily adept|ToB3-Lairs|adepts} present in addition to the prayer leaders.
If the PCs disrupt a prayer session, they are asked to leave. If they persist, Master Miloch along with Adept Toub and Yestel from {@area 1|13.1|u} attempt to coerce them away.

If the PCs are detected searching or stealing in this room, the {@creature serene lily aspirant|ToB3-Lairs|aspirants} and {@creature serene lily adept|ToB3-Lairs|adepts} attempt to detain and secure them in {@area 7|13.7|u}.

entries.name: Development
entries: If the PCs start a fight in this chamber, all abbey residents (except Jaitna) turn against them and fight to the death to protect their compatriots.

entries.name: 7. Excruciation Chamber

entries: A rack and a spiked table occupy much of the space in this chamber, though an iron chair with built-in manacles to secure a humanoid's wrists and ankles is also secured to the floor. Six humanoids can be secured to the wall by manacles attached to iron rings.

A creature who is strapped to the rack or the spiked table can wriggle free by succeeding on a DC 17 Dexterity ({@skill Acrobatics}) check or can break free with a successful DC 20 Strength ({@skill Athletics}) check. Creatures secured with manacles can be freed by picking the locks with a successful DC 16 Dexterity check using {@item thieves' tools|phb}, or they can break free by making a DC 20 Strength ({@skill Athletics}) check.

A creature strapped to the spiked table is {@condition restrained} and takes {@damage 1d4} piercing damage each minute it remains {@condition restrained}; it also takes the same amount of damage any time it attempts to move or take any actions while {@condition restrained}.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: The excruciation chamber is overseen by the ever-present Master Atha (LE {@creature barbed devil} in disguise), who is almost frighteningly cheerful. She answers most questions asked with a lie, and if her deception is discovered, she feigns ignorance.

entries.name: Development
entries: A successful DC 25 Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) check while looking for secret doors discovers the secret door leading to Qudos' redoubt; a successful DC 20 Intelligence ({@skill Investigation}) check is then needed to determine how to open it.

If Master Atha is free, she won't allow the PCs to search the chamber. If she is secured before being questioned, she knows where the secret door is and how to open it, and knows the passphrase to enter {@area 9|13.9|u} from {@area 8|13.8|u} without injury.

entries.name: 8. False Lair

entries: This spartan chamber holds a cot, two tables, some floor pillows, and a wardrobe. It's surprisingly dusty for a living area that is in use. A pair of circles has been etched in the eastern portion of the wall.
Most of the abbey residents believe this dusty chamber is where Abbot Qudos rests, but it's clear no one has stayed here in weeks.

entries.name: Tracks
entries: A track in the dust on the floor runs from {@area 5|13.5|u} to the secret door here in {@area 8|13.8|u}, through the hidden passage to {@area 9|13.9|u}.

entries.name: Development
entries: The location of the secret door in this area is easy to find. A successful DC 15 Intelligence ({@skill Religion}) check determines that the circles etched into the wall form two-thirds of Mammon's holy symbol. If a third circle is traced above the two existing circles, the door opens. If the phrase, "{@i This is the path to profit}," is spoken in {@language Infernal} as the circle is traced, the {@spell glyph of warding} inscribed on the opposite side of the wall is not set off.

If, after the glyph is set off, the PCs attempt a short or long rest in {@area 8|13.8|u} or the passageway leading to {@area 9|13.9|u}, Qudos opens the secret door from {@area 9|13.9|u} to interrupt them, insisting they leave or attacking if they refuse.

A shimmering portal rimmed in crimson and black flames dominates the center of this chamber. On the floor in the center of the northern wall is a small altar surrounded with a hoard of coins and gems.

entries.name: Creatures
entries: Qudos spends most of his time in this chamber, where he confers with Master Ghi and Master Atha or with other devils via the portal. If he is encountered here, he urges the PCs to leave but fights if they refuse to do so. If reduced to 15 hit points or less, he uses his action to {@action Disengage} and exits through the portal; if he's able to flee through the portal, it closes behind him instantly.

entries.name: Development
entries: The portal can be closed by destroying the altar, which has AC 14, 27 hit points, and a damage threshold of 10. If the altar is not destroyed, the portal opens again if items and coin worth more than 1,000 gp are piled on or near it.
If a creature without the fiend type attempts to enter the portal, it bumps into it as if it was a solid object; inanimate objects also cannot pass through it if they are not carried by a fiend.

entries.name: Treasure
entries: The following can be found in this chamber: 3,345 sp, 1,096 gp, a jade and ivory statuette of an elephant (worth 65 gp), a {@item spell scroll (2nd level)||scroll} of {@spell silence}, and a pair of {@item goggles of night}.

entries.name: Concluding the Adventure
entries: If Qudos escapes the PCs, he may return to have his vengeance at a future date, bringing Masters Ghi and Atha if he can. If he is killed, but Ghi and/or Atha escapes, they similarly seek vengeance. Once the abbey is cleared of its infernal residents, it inevitably becomes the lair of some dangerous creature or other group if the PCs don't make an effort to find new residents or render the lair unlivable.
